success-1.title: Inputs to the Change Management Process
body: Documented in a business case or project charter that covers:
- What is the project?
- Why is the project needed (issues and opportunities)?
- How will the project solve the problem or address the opportunity?
- What is the recommended solution?
- What are the risks if the issues and opportunities are not addressed?
- When will the solution be implemented?
- How much money, people and time are required to deliver the solution and realize the benefits?

success-2.title: Defining Success
body: Success includes both project objectives and organizational benefits.
The primary sponsor defines success; the change practitioner documents and socializes it.
To clarify benefits, answer:
- What is the problem or opportunity?
- If solved, what benefit(s) result?
- How will you know the benefits have been realized?

success-3.title: Project Objectives
body: Objectives describe what the project must achieve and align to organizational strategy.
Clarify by asking:
- How will the project help solve the problem or realize the opportunity?
- What will the project produce or enable?
- How will you know the objectives are achieved?

success-4.title: Adoption and Usage Objectives
body: Three people-side factors shape ROI:
- Speed of adoption
- Ultimate utilization
- Proficiency
Define each factor for your change and set measures/targets. Effective change management improves each factor.

success-5.title: Measures of Success
body: Assign quantitative indicators for every project objective and benefit.
Leverage existing metrics where possible.
Without measures, you cannot accurately assess achievement.

success-6.title: Prioritizing Objectives and Benefits
body: Most changes pursue multiple outcomes.
Prioritization helps teams focus effort and make trade-off decisions when facing scope creep, budget cuts, or delays.

success-7.title: Ownership of Objectives and Benefits
body: The primary sponsor is accountable for achieving objectives and benefits.
Large changes require delegating ownership to members of the sponsor coalition so they can lead in their domains and deliver results.

success-8.title: People Dependency of Benefits
body: Structured change management captures the people-dependent share of ROI.
Discuss with sponsors:
- What percentage of outcomes depends on employee adoption and usage?
- How much are we investing (budget, people, energy) to drive that adoption?
Use the answers to calibrate the required investment.

success-9.title: Communicating the Definition of Success
body: a 3 Phase Process begins with defining success to anchor outcomes.
A clear definition positions change management, aligns sponsors and PMs, and supports building Awareness and Desire in ADKAR.

success-10.title: Sponsor Coalition Alignment
body: The primary sponsor leads the sponsor coalition.
Coalition strength depends on members sharing a common definition of success so they can actively drive the change together.

project-1.title: Defining the Change
body: Early in the lifecycle the nature of the change and who is impacted may be unclear, but planning must clarify these points.
Successful changes define:
- The nature of the change.
- The impact on organization, processes, systems, and roles.
- Which individuals and groups are impacted, how, and to what degree.

project-2.title: Project Objectives
body: Objectives align with vision and strategy so that achieving them delivers organizational benefits.
Specific objectives enable measures and targets and contribute to the project definition of success.
They answer:
- How does the project solve the problem or realize the opportunity?
- What will the project produce or enable?
- How will you know the objectives are achieved?

project-3.title: Project Scope
body: Scope defines the work needed to deliver expected outcomes and identifies impacted processes, systems, tools, and structures.
Scope management clarifies what is included versus excluded; capture it early in the lifecycle.

project-4.title: Role of the Project Manager
body: Projects designate a project manager to own planning and control.
In this framework, the project manager:
- Designs, develops, and delivers the technical solution with adoption in mind.
- Collaborates with the change practitioner on a unified approach.
A strong partnership between project manager and change practitioner is essential to achieving objectives and benefits.

project-5.title: Schedules and Milestones
body: The schedule sets start and finish timeframes; milestones mark major activities or deliverables.
Change practitioners align ADKAR milestones to project milestones—for example, Ability aligning with go-live or each release.

project-6.title: Work Breakdown Structure
body: A WBS breaks the work into manageable tasks, often in a tree structure, so the team can visualize dependencies and plan execution.
A solid WBS supports project managers, team members, and stakeholders in understanding complex efforts.

project-7.title: Resource Planning
body: Resources span people, materials, finances, and time.
The schedule and WBS identify who and what is needed, and when, throughout the lifecycle.

project-8.title: Progress Cadence
body: Regular meetings to track progress and resolve issues:
- Keep sponsors and stakeholders informed.
- Surface and remove barriers.
- Create accountability across the sponsor, project team, and stakeholders.

project-9.title: Shared Definition of Success
body: Project management and change management share the goal of achieving objectives and realizing benefits.
Integrated disciplines deliver higher success rates and greater change management effectiveness.
Integration requires the project team to understand the value of change management.

project-10.title: Integrated Planning
body: Project plans focus on technical delivery; change plans focus on people adoption.
Integration yields:
- Shared objectives.
- A proactive approach.
- Better sequencing and alignment.
- Stronger information exchange.
For success, change management must understand project implications and timing, while the project team needs people ready to adopt when the solution ships.

change-1.title: Structured Approach
body: Change management has become more structured over time; using a defined framework is a one of the top success factors.
Organizations with a structured approach see higher change management effectiveness because it creates formal process, common language, and consistent application.

change-2.title: Change Characteristics Assessment
body: Avoid one-size-fits-all: tailor strategy to the nature of the change.
Phase 1 – Prepare Approach uses the Change Characteristics Assessment to evaluate scope, amount, and impact on a spectrum from incremental to disruptive.
Results inform people risk and help customize and scale plans.

change-3.title: Organizational Attributes Assessment
body: Also avoid one-size-fits-all when considering impacted people and the organization.
Phase 1 assesses values, culture, capacity, leadership style, and change history to determine readiness.
Combine these results with change characteristics to gauge people risk and tailor the strategy.

change-4.title: People-Side ROI Factors
body: we need to identify three people-side factors driving ROI:
- Speed of adoption
- Ultimate utilization
- Proficiency
Effective change management boosts each factor; define what they mean and set targets for your change.

change-5.title: Sponsor Coalition Strength
body: Small changes might need only one sponsor, but most require a coalition covering all impacted areas.
The Sponsor Coalition Map highlights functional groups plus formal/informal influencers.
Coalition strength reflects members’ commitment to leading the change in their domains—critical to realizing outcomes.

change-6.title: Phase 1 – Prepare Approach
body: This factor gauges completion of Phase 1 whose purpose is to position the change for success with a tailored strategy and committed sponsorship.
Deliverable: Change Management Strategy built by completing three stages:
- Define Success (What are we trying to achieve?)
- Define Impact (Who changes and how?)
- Define Approach (What will it take?)
Engage broad stakeholders so they own the strategy.

change-7.title: Resourcing Change Management
body: Determine resource needs by considering availability, scale, complexity, people risk, and project timeline.
we need dedicated and sufficient resources toreach higher effectiveness.
Select people with strong communication, change skills, flexibility, and interpersonal strengths.
Prepare the team by teaching the business context, desired outcomes, and change management practices.

change-8.title: Phase 2 – Manage Change: Plan and Act
body: Phase 2 aims to achieve adoption by creating, implementing, and flexing plans that guide ADKAR transitions.
Plan and Act answers: What will we do to prepare, equip, and support people?
For small changes the ADKAR Blueprint may suffice; larger changes expand into core plans such as:
- Sponsor and People Manager Role Plans
- Communications and Training Activity Plans
Tailor each plan to the change context.

change-9.title: Phase 2 – Track and Adapt
body: Also in Phase 2, Track Performance asks “How are we doing?” and Adapt Actions asks “What adjustments are needed?”
Monitoring ADKAR progress reveals when Desire may drop or other building blocks stall, enabling timely course correction.
Measuring progress supports sustainment of outcomes.

change-10.title: Phase 3 – Sustain Outcomes
body: Phase 3 ensures adoption sticks and value is realized.
Stages:
- Review Performance (Where are we now?)
- Activate Sustainment (What actions ensure stickiness?)
- Transfer Ownership (Who owns sustaining outcomes?)
Deliverable: Change Management Closeout that equips the organization to own the change.
Activate Sustainment by identifying gaps and priorities, defining actions/roles/timelines, and preparing/activating sustainment roles.

leadership-1.title: Primary Sponsor Authority
body: The primary sponsor authorizes the change and is accountable for realizing outcomes. Sponsorship level should match change risk.
High-risk changes call for a senior executive with authority over funding, resources, people, processes, and systems.
Effective sponsors stay active and visible, build a coalition, and communicate directly with managers and employees.

leadership-2.title: Explaining the Change
body: People want to hear what is changing, why, and the organizational benefits from the leader in charge.
Sponsors must connect the change to organizational direction and describe risks of not changing.

leadership-3.title: Organizational Vision and Strategy
body: Change projects succeed more often when the organization has a clearly defined vision and strategy.

leadership-4.title: Strategic Alignment
body: A change is aligned when success can be clearly tied to achieving the organization’s strategy.

leadership-5.title: Setting Priorities
body: When multiple initiatives run concurrently, senior leaders must prioritize to allocate limited funds and resources.
Sometimes lower-priority projects must pause so critical initiatives receive what they need to succeed.

leadership-6.title: Decision Making
body: The primary sponsor owns decisions about scope, schedule, and resources.
Every project encounters changes; sponsors need visibility to issues and must resolve them quickly.

leadership-7.title: Active and Visible Sponsorship
body: Being active and visible throughout the lifecycle is one of the sponsor’s three key roles.
Sponsors who show up consistently are seen as transparent, engaged, and committed.

leadership-8.title: Building the Sponsor Coalition
body: Leading a strong sponsor coalition is another key role.
The primary sponsor mobilizes other leaders to advocate for and lead the change in their areas—critical for enterprise changes.
The change practitioner maps the coalition and suggests actions, but the sponsor owns executing them.

leadership-9.title: Building Awareness
body: Creating awareness of the need for change is the third key sponsor role.
Impacted people expect to hear the business rationale and risks from senior leaders.
A visible sponsor legitimizes the change and signals its priority.

leadership-10.title: Reinforcing Success
body: People want success celebrated by the same leader who launched the change.
Sponsors should reinforce wins and tackle resistance to avoid the perception that adoption is optional.
